quiz.title: Unit 1, Quiz 8: Opportunity Cost, Comparative Advantage, PPC Shifts, and Market Systems
quiz.subtitle: AP Macroeconomics — Decision-Making and Trade
quiz.subject: AP Macroeconomics
quiz.topic: Trade-offs, Comparative Advantage, Production Possibilities, Specialization, Prices

questions.question: If a society overallocates its resources, then
options: consumer spending would increase due to an increase in demand
marginal benefit would be greater than marginal cost
the opportunity cost of producing one more unit would increase exponentially
marginal benefit would be less than marginal cost
marginal benefit would equal marginal cost
questions.explanation: Overallocation means too many resources are devoted to producing a good beyond the optimal point where MB = MC. Beyond that point, marginal benefit < marginal cost.

questions.question: Both Luca and Sarah can weed the garden and walk their dog on Sunday morning. For every half hour of walking the dog, Luca can weed twice the amount of garden Sarah can. According to this information,
options: Sarah walks the dog because she has absolute advantage in weeding the garden
Luca walks the dog because he has comparative advantage in weeding the garden
Luca weeds the garden because he has comparative advantage in weeding the garden
Sarah weeds the garden because she has comparative advantage in weeding the garden
Sarah walks the dog because she has absolute advantage in walking the dog
questions.explanation: Luca has absolute advantage in weeding (twice as much as Sarah in same time), but neither has absolute advantage in walking the dog (both take 0.5 hour per walk). Comparative advantage is found by comparing opportunity costs: Sarah's OC of walking is 1 unit weeding, Luca's is 2 units weeding → Sarah has comparative advantage in walking, Luca in weeding. Thus Luca weeds.

questions.question: Joe is in training, hoping he will make the varsity football team next season. He will usually train for five hours a day, four days a week. On the last day of training before tryouts, Joe decides to train one extra hour. Joe’s decision is worth it if which of the following is TRUE?
options: Joe should continue training for an extra hour if he thinks the extra practice will help him get on the team.
Joe should continue training an extra hour if the marginal cost is greater than the marginal benefit.
Joe should continue training an extra hour if the marginal benefit is greater than the marginal cost.
Joe should not continue training an extra hour, because the opportunity cost is too great
Joe should not continue training an extra hour, because the opportunity cost is equal to the decision to train
questions.explanation: Rational choice: engage in an activity if marginal benefit > marginal cost.

questions.question: Which of the following will cause an outward shift of the production possibilities curve?
options: Cuts in funding in educational training for employees
A decrease in a nation’s birthrate, thus decreasing the labor force
A natural disaster creating extreme limitations of a vital natural resource
An increase in skilled workers
None of the above
questions.explanation: Increase in skilled workers increases productive capacity → PPC shifts outward. Others reduce capacity or leave it unchanged.

questions.question: The term ceteris paribus means
options: if event A precedes event B, A caused B
economics deals with facts, not values
other things equal
prosperity inevitably follows recession
out of many one
questions.explanation: Ceteris paribus = 'all else equal', used in economics to isolate the effect of one variable.

questions.question: How is it possible for a country to obtain more than its production possibilities curve dictates?
options: Not possible without greater quantities of the factors of production already obtained
Specialization and trade
Increase in education and job training
Obtainment of a greater quantity of affordable substitutes
Increase in the division of labor
questions.explanation: Through specialization according to comparative advantage and trade, a country can consume beyond its own PPC.

questions.question: Within the market system, prices are determined by
options: supply and demand
a central planning committee
opportunity cost
aggregate demand
the Federal Reserve
questions.explanation: In a market economy, prices are set by the interaction of supply and demand forces.

questions.question: All of the following are examples of macroeconomic variables EXCEPT
options: the price of skateboards sold in the United States between 1995 and 2005
the percentage change in income levels in Kenya between 1980 and 2000
the gross exports of goods out of the United Kingdom in 2010
the average price level of goods in the United States in 2011
the unemployment rate in Germany after World War I
questions.explanation: The price of a specific good (skateboards) is a microeconomic variable; others are aggregate measures (macroeconomics).

questions.question: What does specialization according to comparative advantage allow countries to achieve?
options: Elimination of opportunity costs
Consumption beyond their PPC
Complete self-sufficiency
Reduction in trade deficits
questions.explanation: By specializing and trading, countries can consume at points outside their own production possibilities curve.

questions.question: What does a bowed-out (concave) production possibilities curve indicate about the relationship between two goods as more of one good is produced?
options: Constant opportunity costs, reflecting perfect substitutability between resources.
Variable opportunity costs that fluctuate based on market demand for each good.
Increasing opportunity costs, as resources become less adaptable to producing the other good.
Decreasing opportunity costs, due to economies of scale in production.
questions.explanation: A concave PPC reflects increasing opportunity costs because resources are not perfectly adaptable between uses.

questions.question: What will happen to the opportunity cost of producing cars if a country decides to allocate more resources to car production over computers?
options: The opportunity cost remains the same
The opportunity cost will increase
The opportunity cost will decrease
The opportunity cost will halve
questions.explanation: Given a bowed-out PPC, as more cars are produced, the opportunity cost (computers forgone per additional car) increases because less-suited resources are shifted.

questions.question: A country is choosing to increase spending on public transportation. What is the most likely cause for this?
options: Decrease in human capital
Increase in market shortage
Decrease in quality of natural resources
Increase in physical capital
questions.explanation: Increasing spending on public transportation is an investment in infrastructure, which directly expands a nation's physical capital—human-made resources used to produce goods and services. This is typically done to improve long-term productivity, reduce congestion, and support economic growth.

questions.question: When a country's Production Possibilities Curve shifts outward, which of the following factors is LEAST likely to be the cause?
options: A decrease in the quality of available resources.
Enhanced human capital through improved education and training.
An increase in the quantity of resources, such as labor or capital.
Technological improvements that enhance production efficiency.
questions.explanation: An outward PPC shift indicates growth in productive capacity. Decreased resource quality reduces capacity (shifting curve inward), while improved human capital, increased resources, or better technology can all cause outward shifts.

questions.question: If Country X can produce 8 units of wheat or 4 units of cloth, and Country Y can produce 6 units of wheat or 6 units of cloth, what is a mutually beneficial term of trade for 1 unit of cloth?
options: 0.5 to 1 unit of wheat
2 to 3 units of wheat
1.33 to 2 units of wheat
3 to 4 units of wheat
questions.explanation: Country X's OC of cloth = 2 wheat, Country Y's OC of cloth = 1 wheat. For trade to benefit both, the exchange rate for 1 cloth must be between 1 and 2 wheat. Option C (1.33 to 2 wheat) falls within this range.

questions.question: According to the table shown, if Country C can produce 30 units of Good A or 15 units of Good B and Country D can produce 20 units of Good A or 20 units of Good B, which country has a comparative advantage in producing Good B?
options: Country C
Country D
Both countries share the advantage equally.
Neither country has a clear comparative advantage in Good B.
questions.explanation: Country D's opportunity cost of 1 Good B is 1 Good A (20 Good A ÷ 20 Good B). Country C's opportunity cost of 1 Good B is 2 Good A (30 Good A ÷ 15 Good B). Since Country D has a lower opportunity cost for Good B, it has the comparative advantage in producing Good B.

questions.question: Two nations have the following production capabilities per day: Nation X can produce 8 computers or 24 bicycles; Nation Y can produce 12 computers or 24 bicycles. If they agree to trade at a rate of 1 computer for 2 bicycles, which statement is correct?
options: The terms of trade benefit both nations
Only Nation X benefits from this trade
Only Nation Y benefits from this trade
The terms of trade are outside the acceptable range
questions.explanation: Nation Y's OC of 1 computer is 2 bicycles; Nation X's OC is 3 bicycles. At a trade rate of 1 computer = 2 bicycles, Y receives exactly its OC (no gain), while X pays less than its OC (3 bicycles) so X benefits. Hence only X gains.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a similarity between trade-offs and opportunity costs?
options: Both only apply when decisions involve public goods and governmental choices.
Both require the decision maker to choose between options that yield identical benefits.
Both involve sacrificing one option in favor of another due to the limitations imposed by scarce resources.
Both imply that the selected option will always have a greater monetary value than the forgone alternative.
questions.explanation: Both concepts arise from scarcity: trade-offs are the choices, opportunity cost is the value of the best forgone alternative.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of allocative efficiency?
options: Producing more goods than ever before
Producing the optimal mix of goods society most desires
Producing goods at the lowest possible cost
Producing a wide variety of goods
questions.explanation: Allocative efficiency occurs when the mix of goods produced matches society's preferences (MB = MC for each good). Productive efficiency is about lowest cost.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of trade-offs, comparative advantage, and PPC applications.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review comparative advantage calculations and opportunity cost dynamics.
scoreMessages.50: Needs focus on PPC shifts, comparative vs. absolute advantage, and marginal decision-making.
scoreMessages.0: Revisit core concepts: scarcity, trade-offs, opportunity cost, comparative advantage, and production possibilities.
